org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver

Class TemplateResolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.freemarker.core.templateresolver.TemplateResolver
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultTemplateResolver

    public abstract class TemplateResolver
extends Object
    This class allows users to fully implement the template lookup, loading and caching logic, in case the standard mechanism (a DefaultTemplateResolver combined with all the Configuration settings like templateLoader, templateConfigurations, etc.) is not flexible enough. The TemplateResolver is put into use by setting the templateResolver configuration setting.

    A custom TemplateResolver can depend on a selected set of Configuration settings; the same ones that DefaultTemplateResolver depends on. These settings are collected into the TemplateResolverDependencies class, and the TemplateResolver should get them in initialize() via getDependencies(). It's possible that the custom TemplateResolver only uses some of these settings, which should be reflected by the return value of the supportsXxxSetting methods (like supportsTemplateLoaderSetting()). (Note that there's no supportsXxxSetting method for templateLanguage and sourceEncoding, as the must always be supported and are always exposed.) TemplateResolverDependencies will also expose the TemplateResolverDependencies.parse(org.apache.freemarker.core.TemplateLanguage, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.io.Reader, org.apache.freemarker.core.TemplateConfiguration, java.nio.charset.Charset, java.io.InputStream) method, which is used to create a Template from its source code in the later getTemplate(String, Locale, Serializable) calls.

      • setDependencies

        public final void setDependencies(TemplateResolverDependencies dependencies)
        Called by FreeMarker when the Configuration is built; normally you do not call it yourself. This automatically calls initialize().
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If this method was already called with another Configuration instance.

        protected TemplateResolverDependencies getDependencies()
        Returns null before initialize()

      • initialize

        protected abstract void initialize()
                            throws ConfigurationException
        You meant to initialize the instance here instead of in the constructor. This is called only once (by FreeMarker at least), when the setDependencies(TemplateResolverDependencies) dependencies} is called.
        Throws:
        ConfigurationException

      • checkInitialized

        protected void checkInitialized()
        Checks if the TemplateResolver was fully initialized. It's a good practice to call this at the beginning of most method.

      • getTemplate

        public abstract GetTemplateResult getTemplate(String name,
                                              Locale locale,
                                              Serializable customLookupCondition)
                                       throws MalformedTemplateNameException,
                                              ParseException,
                                              IOException
        Retrieves the parsed template with the given name (and according the specified further parameters), or returns a result that indicates that no such template exists. The result should come from a cache most of the time (avoiding I/O and template parsing), as this method is typically called frequently.

        All parameters must be non-null, except customLookupCondition. For the meaning of the parameters see Configuration.getTemplate(String, Locale, Serializable, boolean). Note that name parameter is not normalized; you are supposed to call normalizeRootBasedName(String) internally.

        Returns:
        A GetTemplateResult object that contains the Template, or a GetTemplateResult object that contains null as the Template and information about the missing template. The return value itself is never null. Note that exceptions occurring during template loading mustn't be treated as a missing template, they must cause an exception to be thrown by this method instead of returning a GetTemplateResult. The idea is that having a missing template is normal (not exceptional), because of how some lookup strategies work. That the backing storage mechanism should indeed check that it's missing though, and not cover an error as such.
        Throws:
        MalformedTemplateNameException - If the name was malformed. This is certainly originally thrown by normalizeRootBasedName(String); see more there.
        IOException - If reading the template has failed from a reason other than the template is missing. This method should never be a TemplateNotFoundException, as that condition is indicated in the return value.
        ParseException

      • clearTemplateCache

        public abstract void clearTemplateCache()
                                 throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Clears the cache of templates, to enforce re-loading templates when they are get next time; this is an optional operation.

        Note that if the TemplateResolver implementation uses TemplateLoader-s, it should also call TemplateLoader.resetState() on them.

        This method is thread-safe and can be called while the engine processes templates.

        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - If the TemplateResolver implementation doesn't support this operation.

      • removeTemplateFromCache

        public abstract void removeTemplateFromCache(String name,
                                             Locale locale,
                                             Serializable customLookupCondition)
                                      throws IOException,
                                             UnsupportedOperationException
        Removes a template from the template cache, hence forcing the re-loading of it when it's next time requested; this is an optional operation. This is to give the application finer control over cache updating than the templateUpdateDelayMilliseconds setting alone gives.

        For the meaning of the parameters, see getTemplate(String, Locale, Serializable)

        This method is thread-safe and can be called while the engine processes templates.

        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - If the TemplateResolver implementation doesn't support this operation.
        IOException

      • toRootBasedName

        public abstract String toRootBasedName(String baseName,
                                       String targetName)
                                throws MalformedTemplateNameException
        Converts a name to a template root directory based name, so that it can be used to find a template without knowing what (like which template) has referred to it. The rules depend on the name format, but a typical example is converting "t.ftl" with base "sub/contex.ftl" to "sub/t.ftl".

        Some implementations, notably DefaultTemplateResolver, delegate this task to a TemplateNameFormat.

        Parameters:
        baseName - Maybe a file name, maybe a directory name. The meaning of file name VS directory name depends on the name format, but typically, something like "foo/bar/" is a directory name, and something like "foo/bar" is a file name, and thus in the last case the effective base is "foo/" (i.e., the directory that contains the file). Not null.
        targetName - The name to convert. This usually comes from a template that refers to another template by name. It can be a relative name, or an absolute name. (In typical name formats absolute names start with "/" or maybe with an URL scheme, and all others are relative). Not null.
        Returns:
        The path in template root directory relative format, or even an absolute name (where the root directory is not the real root directory of the file system, but the imaginary directory that exists to store the templates). The standard implementations shipped with FreeMarker always return a root relative path (except if the name starts with an URI schema, in which case a full URI is returned).
        Throws:
        MalformedTemplateNameException

      • normalizeRootBasedName

        public abstract String normalizeRootBasedName(String name)
                                       throws MalformedTemplateNameException
        Normalizes a template root directory based name (relative to the root or absolute), so that equivalent names become equivalent according String.equals(Object) too. The rules depend on the name format, but typical examples are "sub/../t.ftl" to "t.ftl", "sub/./t.ftl" to "sub/t.ftl" and "/t.ftl" to "t.ftl".

        Some implementations, notably DefaultTemplateResolver, delegates this check to a TemplateNameFormat. The standard TemplateNameFormat implementations shipped with FreeMarker always return a root relative path (except if the name starts with an URI schema, in which case a full URI is returned), for example, "/foo.ftl" becomes to "foo.ftl".

        Parameters:
        name - The root based name. Not null.
        Returns:
        The normalized root based name. Not null.
        Throws:
        MalformedTemplateNameException

      • supportsTemplateLoaderSetting

        public abstract boolean supportsTemplateLoaderSetting()
        Tells whether the TemplateResolver implementation depends on the templateLoader Configuration. If it returns false then this TemplateResolver must not call TemplateResolverDependencies.getTemplateLoader(), or else that will throw IllegalStateException. Furthermore if the user sets the templateLoader in the Configuration to non-null value (the default is null), then the Configuration constructor will throw an exception to tell the user that the templateLoader setting is not supported by this TemplateResolver class. Some may feel tempted to return true to avoid such error, but consider that as the user has explicitly set this setting, they certainly expect it have an effect, and will be frustrated when it doesn't have any.

      • supportsTemplateCacheStorageSetting

        public abstract boolean supportsTemplateCacheStorageSetting()
        Works like supportsTemplateLoaderSetting(), but for the templateCacheStorage setting.
